He will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy more stock of soda. His business goal is to own a big soda depot within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will support his family. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of soda

loans.name: Muranga Upendo Women Group

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand in the photo is Salome. She is married and blessed with three children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in December 2013.

Salome is a maize and beans farmer; and she also keeps poultry. She is grateful to HiHEA for developing her entrepreneurial spirit through training and mentorship.

She is borrowing a Kiva loan to start a cereals business and to purchase fertilizer and seeds that will boost her farming. She hopes to get more profits from the sale of eggs and cereals.

This will enable her to support her family's needs, such as education, food and medical care.

Salome is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for their support. She promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy cereals and fertilizer and seeds that will boost her farming.

loans.name: Rajabmo

texts.ru: Рачабмо 56 лет. Она серьезная и честная женщина. У Рачабмо один сын и одна невестка. Ее сын вместе с ее мужем находится на заработках в Российской Федерации. Они не нашли себе подходящую работу в стране. Рачабмо проживает вместе с невесткой. Рачабмо дехканка. Она работает на большой поле. Рачабмо выращивает хлопок. Ей тяжело работать одна на земле, и ей помогает ее невестка. Рачабмо любит трудиться и собрать богатый урожай. Скора сбор урожай, и Рачабмо хочет обработать растение  минеральными удобрениями. Минеральные удобрения помогает собрать богатый и качественный урожай. С такими планами Рачабмо обратилась к Вам за кредитом. Она ждет Вашу поддержку.
texts.en:
Rajambo is 56 years old. She is a serious and honest woman. Rajambo has one son and one daughter-in-law. Her son together with her husband are migrant workers in the Russian Federation. They were unable to find appropriate work in their country. Rajambo lives together with her daughter-in-law. Rajambo is a farmer. She works on a big field. She grows cotton. It is hard for her to work the land by herself, and her daughter-in-law helps her. Rajambo likes to work and gather a rich harvest. 

Soon it will be harvesting time, and Rajambo would like to treat her [field] with mineral fertilizers, which will  allow her to harvest plentiful high-quality produce. In view of these plans, Rajambo has applied to you for a loan. She is counting on your support.

loans.use: to stock up on mineral fertilizers.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine operates a sari-sari store business in her neighborhood. She is from Duero, Bohol. This business was started in 2010 and she is selling vinegar, soy sauce, corn starch, sugar, milk, milo sachets, powdered detergent, coffee, matches, canned corned beef, beef loaf, sardines, creamer and shampoo.

She is asking for a loan to buy more stock of toothpaste, shampoo, insect repellent, canned sardines, seasonings, detergent powder, soy sauce, vinegar and bath soap. This will allow her to cater to more buyers in her store. This is always the way to keep them and compete well with other stores in the area. Her income goes towards the education of her four children.

loans.use: to buy more stock of toothpaste, shampoo, insect repellent, canned sardines, seasonings, detergent powder, soy sauce, vinegar and bath soap.

loans.name: Juan Alexander

texts.es:
Juan con 28 años de edad,de estado civil conviviente, vive en casa familiar, junto a su cónyuge y hijo , en el distrito de Cayalti, provincia de Chiclayo,departamento de Lambayeque,país Perú.Los habitantes de esta localidad se dedican en su mayoría a la agricultura,comercio y ganadería.

Juan se dedica a las actividad de jornaleria agrícola en los diferentes campos de Cayalti y Zaña,con una experiencia en el rubro desde hace más de 10 años. Solicita préstamo para la comprara algunas herramientas de trabajo y realizará para otro gastos diversos. Con esta inversión realizará mejor su trabajo.

Juan es socio recurrente para Epyme Alternativa. Ha manejado 01 crédito el cuál lo canceló de forma puntual.
texts.en:
Juan is 28 years old. He is in a common law marriage and lives in a family home with his spouse and child in the district of Cayalti, province of Chiclayo, department of Lambayeque in Peru. The residents of this locality mostly work in agriculture, commerce and ranching.

Juan works as an agricultural laborer in different fields of Cayalti and Zaña. He has more than 10 years' experience. He is asking for the loan to buy different work tools and pay for other expenses. With this investment, we will do his work better.

Juan is a returning member of Epyme Alternativa. He has had one loan before, which he paid off on time.

loans.use: to buy some work tools and pay for other expenses.

loans.name: Future Ladies Group

texts.en:
Nyadzai is a member of Future Ladies Group, which came into existence in December 2013. She is a zealous and hardworking woman aged 25 with only one child and stays at the house of her in-laws. When this group came to Thrive, Nyadzai was having an inferiority complex among other group members since she was just running a fruits and vegetables stall whilst other group members had better businesses in terms of size. The group received financial literacy training and a loan from Thrive.

The group repaid their first loan well, however, the change in their businesses was not that significant, so they applied for a further loan. During their second loan, Nyadzai got her breakthough by venturing into mushroom production. She uses a dark room that she controls for diseases and pesticides and harvests once every fortnight and supplies to local supermarkets. She has 100 mushroom kits and every kit produces at least a kilogram per fortnight. Mushrooms have since become her cash cow, but she did not abandon her fruit and vegetable stall. Since her business is improving, she is planning to increase her scale of production. To achieve that, she is looking for funding from Thrive to purchase a water pump engine and pipes for connections that will assist her in watering her mushrooms. As a group they are applying for a combined loan of $3,000.

loans.use: to purchase a water pump engine and pipes for her mushroom-growing business.

loans.name: Shanduko Group

texts.en:
Catherine is a 40-year-old widow staying in a busy suburb of Harare. After the death of her husband around 10 years ago, the burden of taking care of her family fell on her shoulders. This forced her to change from homemaker to homemaker and breadwinner. She started traveling to South Africa to buy clothes and began selling them to her neighbours. This, however, proved to be difficult since there were already some established sellers in the area.

She started selling her clothes in the rural areas of Mhangura. The people in the rural areas did not have cash so she barter traded her clothes for farm maize, which she then sold to her neighbours. The demand for mealie meal has always been high since it is the staple food in Zimbabwe. Travelling up and down proved to be costly for Catherine, so in March of this year she and three other women approached Thrive Microfinance for a loan so that she could restock in high quantities. However, the loan they received in March was still not enough for Catherine and her other group members to reach their goal.

They have approached Thrive Microfinance for another loan of $1,200, hoping that it will help them boost their businesses so that they can break free from poverty. Catherine will use her portion of the loan to buy a wide variety of clothes in large quantities and travel to the farms to sell these clothes. She also plans to have a grinding mill constructed so that she will grind the maize into mealie meal and label it herself.

loans.use: to buy a wide variety of clothes in large quantities and travel to the farms to sell these clothes.

loans.name: Sabiha

texts.en: Sabiha is a 58-year-old married woman. She has been involved in the cloth trade business. She purchases a variety of cloth at low prices from the city market and sells it in her own town. She has a strong customer base. Sabiha has requested a loan of 60,000 PKR. She wants to buy a greater variety of cloth in different colors for her business to get a boost in her earnings with her loan.

loans.use: to buy a greater variety of cloth in different colors for her business to get a boost in her earnings with her loan.

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en:
It was hard for Sakina to manage her household expenses with the small income of her husband. Sakina is a 45-year-old married woman. She is the mother of nine children. Some years ago she started her business selling animals in her community. Her husband fully supports and assists her with her work.

Now, she has requested a loan of 35,000 PKR. She wants to use this loan amount to purchase more cattle for reselling in the market. Sakina has gained great confidence in the business as she has learnt how to deal with other individuals within the business, allowing her to feel empowered.

loans.use: to purchase more cattle for reselling in the market

loans.name: Roxana Yamilet

texts.es:
Roxana, es una mujer casada que vive con su suegra y sus dos hijos; se dedica a la venta de tortillas desde hace dos años, apertura la tortillería desde las 9:00 a.m. hasta las 2:00 p.m. y su suegra es quien le ayuda a la elaboración de las mismas.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de una cocina industrial y de maíz, para aumentar la producción de tortillas y obtener mayores ingresos económicos para ella y su familia.
El sueño de Roxana es invertir lo mejor que se pueda el crédito y a su vez crecer económicamente y así tener una vida más digna y placentera junto a su familia.
texts.en: Roxana is a married woman that lives with her mother-in-law and two children. She has been engaged in selling tortillas for two years.  She opens the tortilla shop from 9:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m., and her mother-in-law helps her make the tortillas.  She is requesting the loan to purchase an industrial kitchen and corn to increase the production of tortillas, and obtain more income for herself and her family.  Roxana’s dream is to invest the loan the best that she can, and in turn, grow financially, and thus have a more decent and pleasant life with her family.

loans.use: to purchase an industrial kitchen and corn to increase the production of tortillas.

loans.name: Trust Group

texts.en:
As they say “experience is the best teacher”, and Josephine, a 54-year-old widow, has been an entrepreneur since 1987. In that year she attended a Knitting and Crocheting Course and started knitting jerseys and selling them to school children.

Around 2009 there was a slump in businesses, not only in Zimbabwe but also in the whole world, which affected the grassroots business persons, including people like Josephine.

Her business suffered a huge blow, but as someone who was determined, she did not quit. Instead she thought of diversifying, since "putting all her eggs in one basket" proved not to be working.

She built a fowl run and started raising broilers. She started with a small batch of 50 chicks and grew the batch size to 100 chicks over the years. Now she sells a hundred broilers every 3 weeks. She has built another fowl run and modeled it to house egg layers.

Josephine needs a loan so that she can buy some chickens at the point they begin laying. This will increase her revenue, as she will now not only be selling chickens, but eggs as well.

She has not abandoned her jersey knitting business, so she is looking to stock wool in bulk ahead of the coming year when pupils will need new jerseys. She has four dependents she looks after, and as a business person, she is able to meet her household needs through these business ventures.

Through the training she received from Thrive, she is now intellectually active and she is managing her business well. She and her neighbors have been able to join hands to form the Trust group.

loans.use: to buy some chickens at the time they begin laying. This will increase her revenue as she will now not only be selling chickens, but eggs as well.

loans.name: Ivowali Group

texts.en:
Omari, who is in his late 50s is married with four kids; two of whom are still in school while the others are grown-up. He has been running several business, selling soft drinks and food vending (mama lishe) for twenty-two years now. He works from 8 am to 10 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Omari's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to increase his mama lishe stock and to start selling soft drinks.

Omari is happy with the loan and appreciates Kiva for supporting their group. He used the profit to pay school fees for his two kids, to buy two TVs, speakers, a bed and to cover household expenses.

Omari will use this loan to increase his business stock such as soft drinks as well as to buy the missing items for his mama lishe store.

He dreams of expanding and making progress in his business.

loans.use: to buy items such as soft drinks as well as to buy the missing items for his mama lishe (mother nutrition) store.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman. She has two children. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

She will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. She hopes that in the future she will be successful. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Priscilla

texts.en: Priscilla is married and has two children. She describes herself to be loyal. For the past five years, Priscilla has operated a retail business where she sells sugar, soda, flour, rice, bread and other items. Her primary customers are locals. Priscilla describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, soda, flour, bread and other items. Priscilla will use the anticipated profits to start a new business.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, soda, flour, bread and other items.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a married woman. She has 2 children, ages 6 and 11 years. She operates a farm where she keeps dairy cows and also grows crops. Her business is located in a fertile area and her primary customers are locals.

Nancy will use the Kes 40,000 loan to buy a water tank to store clean water for domestic use. She hopes that in the future, she will improve her family. This is her fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy a water tank to store clean water

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina is aged 58, married to a farmer and they're blessed with three children. She has owned and managed a retail store in their village for almost 30 years, earning a net income of approximately PHP 500 a day.

Due to insufficient capital in her business, she would like to get a loan amounting to PHP 50,000 to purchase canned goods, coffee, sugar, cooking oil, soy sauce and vinegar to sell.

Josefina's hoping that her retail store will continue to grow productively and profitably.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, coffee, sugar, cooking oil, soy sauce and vinegar to sell.

loans.name: Grupo Chuatzam Group

texts.es:
Marcos es un gran hombre con grandes virtudes, él es amable, generoso. Él tiene 27 años de edad, con una linda familia de tres hijos de las edades entre 1 y 11 años, esta querida familia vive en una comunidad del caserío Chuatzam.
Marcos (él primero del lado derecho de la fotografía) para obtener algo de ingresos y satisfacer las necesidades de su familia se dedica a la producción de café, esta actividad lo viene realizado él desde hace 7 años. Marcos gracias al liderazgo que posee es el representante del grupo  denominado Grupo Chuatzam. Marcos para obtener una buena cosecha al final de este año ha tomado la decisión de solicitar un préstamo para la compra de fertilizantes y pago de mano de obra para el mantenimiento de su cultivo de café. Su gran sueño es obtener una buena cosecha para mejorar los ingresos económicos de su familia.
texts.en:
Marcos is a great man with many abilities, and he is friendly and generous. He is 27 years old with a beautiful family of three children ages 1 to 11 years. This dear family lives in a community in the village of Chuatzam.

To obtain some income and meet the needs of his family, Marcos (first from the right in the photograph) is engaged in coffee production, and he has been engaged in this activity for three years. Thanks to his leadership skills, Marcos is the representative of the Chuatzam communal bank. To obtain a good harvest at the end of this year, Marcos has decided to request a loan to buy fertilizers and pay for labor costs to maintain his coffee crops. His dream is to obtain a good harvest to improve his family’s income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Viana Zunilda

texts.es: Viana de 36 años habita en Barranquilla en compañía de su cónyuge y su hijo de 10 años.  Ella se inició en el comercio motivada por la propuesta que recibió de una amiga que por años ha comercializado ropa interior de excelente calidad, aliada con una empresa de multinivel que promueve distintos productos a través de la oferta del catálogo.  Hace dos años decidió hacer parte de esta forma masiva de comercialización mostrando óptimos resultados, con los que ha favorecido la economía de la familia.  Cualquier día de la semana Viana está dispuesta a exhibir el catálogo de ropa interior a vecinos y amigos del sector donde reside, así como a sus familiares y referidos. Viana está muy contenta y  se visiona a futuro comercializando otras gamas de productos que le generen otros ingresos adicionales. En la actualidad realizó una solicitud de crédito, su primer credikiva por intermedio de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para invertir en mercancía; brasieres, pantis, bóxer, camisillas y accesorios. Con este préstamo logrará abastecer todas las solicitudes que sus clientes le realicen sin imprevistos.
texts.en:
36-year-old Viana lives in Barranquilla with her husband and her 10-year-old son. She was motivated to start her business because of the offer she received from a friend who, for years, had been selling excellent quality undergarments, allied with a multi-level company that sells various products through catalog sales.

Two years ago, she decided to become part of this mass marketing, showing optimal results which have benefit the family economy. Any day of the week, Viana is ready to show her catalog of undergarments to neighbors and friends in her neighborhood, as well as her family and clients who are referred to her.

Viana is very happy and she sees herself selling other product lines in the future which would generate additional income for her. Currently, she applied for a loan, her first Kiva loan through the Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo, to invest in merchandise; bras, panties, boxers, undershirts and accessories. With this loan, she will be able to fill all of the orders that her clients make without issue.

loans.use: to invest in merchandise; bras, panties, boxers, undershirts and accessories.

loans.name: Ana Yancy

texts.es:
Ana, vive en casa de sus padres junto a su hijo de 7 años de edad, ella es propietaria de una sala de belleza la cual fundo hace 5 años con capital propio, todos los días ella se levanta con toda la disposición del mundo para poder atender a sus clientes en horarios de 8:00 a.m. hasta las 5:00 p.m. 
Solicita el crédito para poder abastecer de mercadería su salón de belleza comprara tratamientos para el cabello, shampoo y tintes; de esa manera ella pretende poder incrementar su inventario para poder atender mejor a sus clientes y así poder obtener más ingresos económicos para darle una mejor calidad de vida a su hijo.
Ella sueña con tener un negocio más competitivo en la zona para en un futuro ser una gran empresaria.
texts.en:
Ana lives in her parents' house with her 7 year old son. She is the owner of a beauty salon which she opened 5 years' ago with her own capital. She gets up everyday with all of the enthusiasm of the world to serve her customers from 8:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m.

She is asking for the loan to stock up on merchandise for her beauty salon. She will buy hair treatments, shampoo and dyes. With this she intends to increase her inventory to obtain more income to give her son a better quality of life.

Her dream is to have a more competitive business in the area so that in the future she will be a great business woman.

loans.use: to buy hair treatments, shampoo and dyes. With this, she intends to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en:
Financial constraints alongside the want for a better life and good quality education for her 4 children are only a few, but valuable factors that encouraged our Shahnaz to start her business by taking a loan from Kashf Foundation. Her business is selling animals.

Shahnaz is 35 years old and a married woman. She buys animals (baby goats & calves) at low prices, brings them up and then sells them out in the market at higher prices.

She makes enough through her business to contribute to the family income. She also sells milk to generate an extra amount of income. She needs to improve her business to bear her household expenses.

For this reason, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of PKR 40,000 to purchase more animals to inflate her sales.

Shahnaz is very experienced and has good contacts in the market. With this loan, she will definitely expand her business and increase her income.

loans.use: to purchase more animals to inflate her sales

loans.name: Anadelle

texts.en:
Anadelle is a married woman from the town of Duero in Bohol. Having four children aged one to eleven is a challenge for Anadelle when she is without a job.

Anadelle helped her husband, who is working as a habal-habal driver (motorcycle transport) to make both ends meet. She usually cooks snacks such as camote cues (deep-fried sweet potato in caramelized sugar), banana cues (deep-fried banana in caramelized sugar) and rice cakes. She has had this business for seven years now.

Anadelle is requesting a loan from CEVI to buy additional ingredients such as bananas, sweet potatoes, brown sugar, cooking oil and skewers. She will also spend some of the amount on the maintenance and repair of their motorcycle.

She hopes to make her business successful so that she can continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as bananas, sweet potatoes, brown sugar, cooking oil, skewers, and to pay for motorcycle maintenance.

loans.name: Crusita

texts.en:
Crusita is a 54-year-old married woman from Duero, Bohol. She is a mother to three teenagers. To provide for them she buys and sells rice. With every household and family eating rice, she never runs out of orders.

Crusita is asking for a loan to buy more rice to sell. With this, she will be able to sell more to the people in her community. That will enable her to generate a stable revenue for her family.

In the future, she hopes that all her children will be successful in their studies.

loans.use: to buy rice to sell

loans.name: Elvis

texts.es:
Elvis con 30 años de edad,de estado civil conviviente, vive junto a su cónyuge y dos 2 hijos, en el distrito de Oyotún, provincia de Chiclayo,departamento de Lambayeque,país Perú,una zona rural. Elvis cuenta con muy buenas referencias tanto personales como laborales. Los habitantes de esta localidad se dedican en su mayoría a la agricultura,comercio y ganadería.

Elvis se dedica a brindar los servicios agrícolas de jornalería,contando con herramientas propias, como palana, pico, oz y mochila de fumigar, con más de 05 años de experiencia en el negocio. Solicita préstamo para arreglos de vivienda y para mantenimiento de equipos y herramientas, dicha inversión le servirá para tener en mejores condiciones sus equipos y herramientas, con gran influencia en el negocio De esta manera piensa mejorar la productividad de sus servicios y así poder atender las diversas necesidades de los clientes de la zona.

Elvis es socio nuevo para Edpyme Alternativa. .
texts.en:
Elvis is 30 years old. He is in a common law marriage and he lives with his spouse and their 2 children in the district of Oyotún, province of Chiclayo,department of Lambayeque, in Peru. Elvis has very good references, both personal and professional. The residents of this locality mostly work in agriculture, commerce and ranching.

Elvis works as an agricultural day laborer. He has his own tools, such as a shovel, a pickax, a sickle and a fumigation pack. He has more than 5 years' experience in the business. He is asking for the loan to do home repairs and to do maintenance on his equipment and tools. This investment will help him keep his tools and equipment in better condition and that will really influence his business. He plans to improve his productivity in this way and be able to meet the diverse needs of the customers in the area.

Elvis is a new member of Edpyme Alternativa.

.

loans.use: to do home repair and maintenance on equipment and tools.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is a Kiva borrower who has three children. She describes herself to be honest. For the past seven years, Valentina has operated a retail business where she sells sugar, soda, flour, rice, bread and other items. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals.

Valentina will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, soda, flour, bread and other items. Her business goal is to own more shops within five years. Valentina hopes that, in the future, she will improve her living standards. She will use the anticipated profits to open another shop.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, soda, flour, bread and other items.

loans.name: Kasuku Group

texts.en:
Sylivia, who is in her early thirties, is married with one schooling child. She has been running two projects, selling cosmetics and madila, for one year now. She works from 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a very good monthly profit.

This will be Sylivia's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to increase her cosmetics stock, bought a glass cupboard for keeping cosmetics, and started selling madila. She has managed to pay back her loan successfully. She used the profit to pay school fees, to repay the loan, and cover household expenses.

She will use this loan to buy the best-selling cosmetics and to increase her madila stock. She dreams of building her own house.

Sylivia will share this loan with her loan group, Kasuku, which has two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy the best-selling cosmetics and to increase her madila (dresses) stock.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina, a 52-year-old, married woman, resides in the town of Talibon, Bohol. She engages in farming and grows rice. She has a 16-year-old dependent. Her husband is also a farmer. They work together to support their family. She has been engaged in farming for 10 years now.

Marcelina has requested a loan to buy fertilizers, medicine and pay the laborer. With the loan, she could help boost the farm yield and continue to improve her earnings. Thus, she could be able to continue to provide for her family and continue to support the schooling of her child.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, medicine and pay the laborer.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a married woman. She has four children. She describes herself to be kind. She operates a farm where she grows bananas and onions. She has been involved in this business for 12 years. Her business is located in a fertile area.

She will use the KES 100,000 loan to buy farm inputs. This will enable her to increase production. She hopes that in the future, she will improve her living standards.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Marifi

texts.en:
Marifi is aged 43, single and a mother of two children. She has owned and managed a retail store in her village for almost eight years and earns a net income of PHP 1,200 daily. Her net income goes usually in her savings.

Due to insufficient funds for her business, she would like to take a loan amounting to PHP 15,000 to purchase cooking oil, sugar, salt, fish sauce, beverages, soy sauce, and vinegar to sell. She's hoping that her business will continue to improve and become more profitable.

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil, sugar, salt, fish sauce, beverages, soy sauce, and vinegar to sell.

loans.name: Nairo

texts.en:
Nairo is a married woman. She has two children. She describes herself to be intelligent. She operates a farm where she grows bananas and maize. She has been involved in this business for six years. Her business is located in a fertile area, and her primary customers are locals.

She will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy farm inputs. She hopes that in the future, she will have an educated family.

This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to cater to the family's needs.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Merumi

texts.en:
Merumi is a married man. He has three children. He describes himself to be polite. He operates a retail business where he sells sugar, rice, flour, sweets and other items. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located in a busy area, and his primary customers are locals.

He will use the KES 70,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, rice, flour, bread, cooking oil, and sweets. His business goal is to have more shops within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will improve his living standards.

This is his fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to open another shop.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, rice, flour, bread, cooking oil, and sweets.

loans.name: Linneth Milena

texts.es:
Linneth Milena tiene 30 años de edad, es madre de 3 hijos y obtuvo su bachillerato en secundaria, vive con su compañero, quien trabaja en una empresa de venta de electrodomésticos y le apoya como fiador en esta solicitud, uno de sus hijos está en primaria y los otros no están en edad escolar, por lo que recibe el apoyo de su mamá para cuidarlos y de su esposo en sus ratos libre, para así poder dedicarse a su profesión de comerciante. Inicia hace ya 4 años con un producto que una proveedora le da en consignación, valorado en ¢ 200.000, ella lo vende obtiene un capital adicional y una clientela estable. Continua en el comercio desde entonces;  está  solicitando su primer  crédito y presenta buenas referencias de sus clientes y proveedor. Comercializa ropa interior, ropa de hombre y de niño para toda la familia, su herramienta principal es su bicicleta, con la que se desplaza en la comunidad cobrando y entregando su mercadería.


 Presenta buena gestión de su negocio, según la información que arroja el análisis hecho a su microempresa, le permite recuperar sus cuentas a tiempo para volver  a invertir la limitante ha sido la falta de dinero para poder crecer y aumentar su cartera de clientes. 

   Atiende un mercado regional, donde cuenta con más de 20 clientas. Busca ofertas de liquidación para mejorar los ingresos de su negocio,  distribuye su mercadería y trabaja durante todo el año, a pesar de la competencia, busca ofrecer a sus clientes facilidades de pago y contar con ropa de temporada, para cubrir los pedidos.
texts.en:
Linneth Milena is 30 years old. She is the mother of 3 children and she graduated from high school. She lives with her partner, who works in a business that sells household appliances. He is supporting her as a guarantor on this loan request. One of their children is in primary school, while the others aren’t school age yet. Her mother helps her take care of them and so does her husband when he has free time. In this way she is able to work in her profession as a merchant. She began 4 years ago with product that a supplier consigns to her for CRC 200,000 (Costa Rica Colon). She sells it and earns some additional capital, along with a stable clientele. She has been working as a merchant since that time. She is requesting her first loan and provides good references from her customers and her provider. She sells intimate clothing, men’s clothes, children’s clothes, clothing for the whole family. An important tool for her is her bicycle, which is how she travels around her community, charging payments and delivering her merchandise.

Her business is functioning well, according to the information in an analysis that was done on it. She is able to recuperate her expenses in time to reinvest. The limiting factor has been a lack of funds to grow and increase her number of clients.

She attends a regional market, where she has more than 20 clients. She looks for good sale prices in order to improve her income. She distributes her merchandise and works during the whole year, despite competition. She offers her clients installment payment options and has seasonal clothing to cover their requests.

loans.use: to buy clothing for women, men, and children; blouses, pants, and similar items.

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es: Hace siete años que Maria Luisa inicio su negocio de pulpería, su esposo ha sido su principal apoyo en el negocio, poco ha ido incrementando las ventas y también los clientes. Maria Luisa desea expandir su negocio y poder surtir la demanda de los clientes con sus productos, es por esta razón que solicita un crédito para comprar arroz, frijoles, azúcar, aceite, productos de aseo personal entre otros. Con esto incrementara sus ganancias y podrá mejorar su estilo de vida.
texts.en: Seven years ago, Maria Luisa started her small grocery store business. Her husband has been very supportive of her business. Little by little, she has increased her sales and also her number of clients. Maria Luisa would like to expand her business and provide for the product requests of her clients. For this reason, she is requesting a loan to buy rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, personal products, etc. With the loan, she will increase her earnings and be able to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, personal products, etc.

loans.name: Herson Aldeir

texts.es:
Herson, de 25 años de edad, estudio hasta bachillerato, está soltero, no tiene hijos y vive con sus padres.

Herson, ha trabajado desde la edad de 10 años junto a su padre, principalmente en la siembra de maíz y frijol; actualmente tiene sembrado 7,000 metros cuadrados de cultivo de maíz y frijol y el lugar donde siembra está a 500 metros de su casa y el trabajo siempre lo realiza con ayuda de su padre, de esta forma obtiene ingresos para ayudar a sus padres.

El crédito lo necesita para comprar insumos agrícolas para aplicarlos a sus cultivos de maíz y frijol.

Herson, sueña con mejorar su vivienda y estudiar una carrera universitaria.
texts.en:
Herson, 25, studied up to high school. He is single, doesn’t have any children, and lives with his parents.

Herson has been working since he was 10 years old, growing corn and beans alongside his father. Currently, he has planted 7,000 square metres of corn and beans in a field that is at a distance of 500 metres from his home. His father always helps him with the work, and, in this way, Herson generates the income to support his parents.

He needs the loan to buy agricultural inputs for his corn and bean crops.

Herson dreams of making some home improvements and pursuing a university degree.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural inputs for his corn and bean crops.

loans.name: Grupo Sector Mangal Group

texts.es:
Santas es madre de familia de 31 años de edad, es casado con una linda familia de un hijo de 5 años de edad, esta humilde familia vive en una comunidad de la aldea Guineales.
Santas con el afán de ofrecerle a su hijo una mejor vida, se dedica a la compra y venta de ropa típica de su región, ella lleva 3 años de realizarlo, durante este tiempo es vendedora ambulante en los distintos mercados circunvecinos.
Santas con el deseo de ofrecer un mejor servicio hacia los clientes a tomado la decisión de solicitar un préstamo para la compra de más mercadería de ropa típica tales como: cortes, güipiles y fajas, pues la época de fin de año se acerca y esto incrementa la demanda de ropa y ella prefiere estar preparada para aprovechar  mejor esta oportunidad.
Sus aspiraciones en la vida es fortalecer su negocio y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Santas is a 31 year old mother. She is married, with a beautiful family and a 5 year old son. This humble family lives in a community in the village of Guineales.

Santas, eager to offer a better life to her son, works buying and selling clothing typical in her area. She has been doing this for 3 years. During this time she has been a street vendor at the different markets close by.

Santas, hoping to offer better service to her customers, has made the decision to request a loan to buy more traditional clothing merchandise like: güipiles (tunic/ blouse), fajas (woven belt) y cortes (handwoven cloth). The end of the year season is close and this increases demand for clothing. She prefers to be prepared in order to better take advantage of this opportunity.

Her ambitions in life are to strengthen her business and improve her family's quality of life.

loans.use: to buy and sell traditional clothing like güipiles (tunic/ blouse), fajas (woven belt) y cortes (handwoven cloth).

loans.name: Ayaba

texts.fr: Mariée, Ayaba est une femme avec quatre enfants à charge. Ayaba est âgée de 52 ans et habite à Baguida où elle prépare et vend de la pâte bandée faite à base du maïs appelée « Akpan » et accompagné des poissons frit puis de l’arachide. Ayaba achète le nécessaire servant à la préparation deux fois par mois au marché et vend sa marchandise à la devanture de son domicile et en parcourant les quartiers environnant. Ayaba demande ce prêt pour commander de sac de maïs et des bols d’arachide en vue de bien revendre puis de gagner plus de bénéfices afin de subvenir à ses besoins et d’améliorer les conditions de vie quotidiennes de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Ayaba is a married woman with four dependent children. She is 52 years old and lives in Baguida. She prepares and sells a  polenta-like cornmeal dish known as "akpan" and sold with fried fish and peanuts. Ayaba buys the necessary ingredients at the market twice a month and sells her food in front of her home and as an itinerant vendor in nearby neighborhoods.

Ayaba is seeking this loan in order to buy a bag of corn and some bowls of peanuts in order to have a good margin and earn more revenues. This will allow her to provide for her needs and improve her children's quality of life.

loans.use: to buy one bag of corn and two bowls of peanuts.

loans.name: Aneth

texts.en:
Aneth, who is in her late 30s, is single with one kid who is still in school. She has been running a retail shop for five years now. She works from 6:30 a.m. to 11 p.m. every day and is able to earn a good monthly profit.

This will be Aneth's 18th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to increase kilos of rice, soap, cooking oil, sugar, beans, salt, sweets, biscuits, etc. She is so thankful with the loan. She earned an extra income which she used to buy a TV set, a radio, a fridge and beds, repaid a loan, paid school fees for her kid and covered household expenses.

She will use this loan to buy sacks of rice, sugar, flours, beans, cooking oil, etc., to meet customers' demand and requests. She dreams of extending her shop.

Aneth will be accountable for paying back her loan.

loans.use: to buy sacks of rice, sugar, flours, beans, cooking oil, etc., to meet customers' demand and requests.

loans.name: Jonaliza

texts.en:
Jonaliza is 37 years old, married and has two children who are going to school. Her husband works abroad while she manages a talipapa, or food stall, selling fish, fruit and vegetables.

Jonaliza had learned how to operate this kind of business from her parents. She wants to continue run her business and gain good profits from it. She is now applying for a 50,000 PHP loan through Kiva's field partner ASKI to buy frozen meat products and more fruits and vegetables to sell.

Jonaliza is working to save money for the future and attain financial stability.

loans.use: to buy frozen meat products and more fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a divorced woman. She has two children. She describes herself to be faithful. She operates a retail business where she sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for eight years. Her business is located in a busy area, and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

She will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of charcoal. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within five years. She will use the anticipated profits to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy more stock of charcoal.

loans.name: Rubilyn

texts.en:
Rubilyn is 40 years old and a single parent. She has owned and operated a retail store in her village for almost five years and earns a net income of 200 PHP a day. Her net income usually goes to her savings.

Due to inadequate capital in her business, she would like to ask for a loan amounting to 20,000 PHP to purchase cooking oil, soy sauce, vinegar, salt, and fish to sell. She's hoping that her income from her business will continue to grow profitably.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil, soy sauce, vinegar, salt, and fish to sell.

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en: Fredrick is a married man. He has two children. He operates a tailoring business where he makes clothes. He has been involved in this business for nine years. His business is located in a busy area and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. He will use the Kes 40,000 loan to buy tailoring materials. He hopes that in the future, he will expand his business. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy tailoring materials

loans.name: Jose Nicolas

texts.es:
Nicolas, de 50 años de edad, estudio hasta tercer grado, se separo de su esposa desde hace tres años y con ella procreo tres hijos y los tres están con la mamá de Nicolas, porque están estudiando.

Nicolas, se dedica a la albañilería desde hace 14 años, este oficio se lo enseño un tío para que le sirviera en el futuro y es de ahí de donde mantuvo a sus hijos.- Nicolas, hoy en día quiere colocar un taller de estructuras metálicas, porque también conoce acerca de este oficio gracias a un primo que le enseño.

Nicolas, necesita el préstamo para comprar un aparato de soldadura nuevo, porque el que tiene lo compro de segunda mano y no hay mucha garantía y ya está terminando su vida útil. 

Los sueños de Nicolas, es seguir trabajando y poder ser un albañil muy reconocido en la comunidad y poder hacer trabajos grandes de estructuras métalicas.
texts.en:
Nicolas is 50 years old, and has a third grade education. He has been separated from his wife for three years, and he has three children with her who are with Nicolas’ mother because they are in school.

Nicolas has been engaged in masonry for 14 years. He learned this trade from his uncle so that it would serve him in the future, and this is how he supports his children. Today, Nicolas wants to set up a metal workshop because he also knows this trade thanks to a cousin that taught it to him.

Nicloas needs the loan to purchase new welding equipment because the one he has he bought second hand, so there is little guarantee, and it is already coming to the end of its useful life.
Nicolas dreams of continuing to work, being able to become a well-known mason in his community, and being able to build great metal works.

loans.use: to purchase new welding equipment because the one he has he bought second hand, so there is little guarantee, and it is already coming to the end of its useful life.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is a married woman. She has six children. She describes herself to be polite. She operates a tailoring business where she makes clothes. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. She will use the Kes 60,000 loan to buy tailoring materials. Her business goal is to have a tailoring firm within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will educate her children to the university level. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loans were repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to expand the business.

loans.use: to buy tailoring materials

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda is a 27-year-old married woman with two young dependents. She lives in the rural town of Talibon, Bohol. She owns rice paddies and grows rice. These serve as her main source of income. Her husband's occupation is a driver.

She has been growing and selling rice for two years now. She would like to boost her business. She joined CEVI to cater to her financial needs.

Melinda is applying for a loan to invest in fertilizer in order to have a good harvest and improve her income. In that way, she will be able to invest in other possible sources of income that could help her to become more sustainable.

loans.use: to invest in fertilizer

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 57 years old and runs a small business selling snacks. She and her husband live in Duero, Bohol with their eighteen-year-old daughter.

With her food equipment, she cooks and sell snacks such as deep-fried bananas in caramelized sugar, cassava cakes, and rice cakes. Teresita is asking for a loan to buy more ingredients like bananas, cassava, and sugar. Her loan will impact her cooking so that she can produce more and sell both in the morning and in the afternoon.

It is her hope that someday she can start a sari-sari store for additional income.

loans.use: to buy bananas, cassava, and sugar.

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle is 46 years old and married with five children. With three children currently in school, Annabelle works very hard to provide for them.

Annabelle runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 17000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks to sell in her general store.

Annabelle has been in this business for 5 years and sells a variety of items such as seasonings, diapers, toothpaste, canned goods, cereals, coffee, etc. 

In the future, Annabelle would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks to sell in her general store

loans.name: Marecel

texts.en:
Marecel's way of earning money is farming. She toils on the land and grows rice. She sells it to the locals and town settlers in her place. Her husband has an income that could support the needs of her family.

She is married and has four children. Her eldest is 11, while the youngest is 4.

She has requested a loan to buy fertilizers. These are vital. These serve as the tool that could generate a bountiful harvest. Thus, it enables her to continue support her family. In that way, she could invest in other sources of income to become sustainable.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers.

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel is a married man. He has four children. He describes himself as honest.

He operates a passenger transportation business, where he transports customers from one town to another. He has been involved in this business for nine years. His primary customer is the general public.

Gabriel will use the 90,000 KES loan to buy another engine for his vehicle.

His business goal is to buy two more motor vehicles within five years. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to buy another vehicle.

loans.use: to buy another engine for his vehicle

loans.name: Precious Tazara Group

texts.en:
Khadija is in her late 30s. She is married with four children in school.  She has been running a grocery store for six years now.  She works from 2am to mid-night daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Kadija's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She will use this loan to buy stock of drinks for her the grocery store.  She dreams of expanding her business into a pub.  

Khadija will share this loan with her loan group Precious which consists of five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy the drinks for her grocery store.

loans.name: Parvina

texts.en: Parvina was born in 1972. . She is a kind and hardworking woman. Parvina is married and has three children. Parvina lives with her family in South Tajikistan. Her daughter Zebo is 18 years old and her sons Aziz and Rustam are schoolboys. Her husband is a pensioner. Parvina is the only breadwinner of the family. She has a farming business. Parvina grows tomatoes and crops such as maize and wheat. She has worked in this field for more than five years and little by little, she developed her business. Parvina is asking for a loan of 5,000 Somoni to buy seeds and mineral fertilizers for new sowing. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy seeds and mineral fertilizers for new sowing.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a married woman. She has six children. She describes herself to be determined. She operates a retail business where she sells sugar, soda, bread, flour, sweets and other items. She has been involved in this business for 15 years. Her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the Kes 70,000 loan to buy more stock of soda, sugar, bread, soap, flour, rice and other items. She hopes that in the future, she will be successful.  She will use the anticipated profits to puchase additional stock.

loans.use: to buy more stock of soda, sugar, bread, soap, flour, rice and other items.

loans.name: Chhon

texts.en:
Chhon, age 51, is a resident of Battambang province. He is married and has three children, one of whom is dependent and still in school. His family’s income comes from working as a rice farmer, teacher and soldier. Chhon has been in his farming business for 33 years. He counts on rainfall to cultivate rice. Unfortunately, there is not enough water to supply the rice field, which means he gets lower-than-expected outputs.

Chhon is now applying for a loan support from VisionFund to pay for school fees for his son so that he can study for a Bachelor's of English Literature. He hopes that this loan will enable his son to study until he graduates and has a bright future.

loans.use: to pay for school fees for his son so that he can study for a Bachelor's of English Literature.

loans.name: Nuevo Retono Group

texts.es:
Ana es una mujer de 31 años de edad, vive con su pareja, tiene 3 hijos de 3, 5 y 11 años y su negocio es la tienda de barrio.
Ella es buena madre, responsable y muy conversadora. Su negocio lo realiza en la zona ‘mutualista’ área central que alberga a la mayor parte de instituciones públicas y privadas, como hospitales, restaurantes, universidades, centros comerciales, etc.
Ana es de piel morena, baja estatura y físico robusto (la primera de la izquierda, viste completamente de negro), su lengua materna es el guaraní que habla en familia y habla español por el comercio que realiza. Su vida la comparte con su pareja que trabaja como ayudante de bus interdepartamental y con sus hijos que estudian en la escuela. Viven en una casa propiedad de la familia construida de ladrillo que cuenta con agua potable, energía eléctrica y alcantarillado. Las ganas de mejorar su negocio la hicieron liderar la banca de emprendimiento, los negocios de los socios son; venta de ropa de segunda mano, venta de comida, venta de salteñas y empanadas, librería, café internet, venta de productos naturales para la salud, venta de cosméticos y confección de sábanas. Su negocio es la venta de artículos y alimentos de primera necesidad en su tienda de barrio, ella vende pan, azúcar, gaseosas, galletas, golosinas, refrescos en sobre y otros, “intento revitalizar mi tienda, que es un centro de reunión de vecinos…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que los vecinos se reúnen para conversar y comprar, la desventaja es la falta de mercadería para ofertar. Su sueño es ser la tienda elegida por los vecinos del barrio, ella desea comprar alimentos para abastecer su negocio. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 1 año que se dedica a esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Ana solicita un préstamo para abastecer su tienda para ser elegida por los vecinos del barrio.
texts.en:
Ana is 31 years old. She is responsible and a good conversationalist. She has her business in a commercially diverse area, which is central to most of the public and private institutions, such as hospitals, restaurants, universities, shopping centers, etc.

Ana is dark and of short stature (the first from the left, wearing all black). Her first language is Guaraní, which she speaks at home. She speaks Spanish when conducting business. She shares her life with her partner, who works as an assistant on an interdepartmental bus and with her children, who are studying in school. They live in their own house, which is constructed of brick, has running water, electricity and is connected to the city sewer. Her desire to improve her business motivated her to become the leader of her communal bank. The members’ businesses are: second-hand clothing sales, food sales, sweet empanadas and savory empanadas, book store, internet café, natural health products sales, cosmetics sales, and making sheets. 

Ana’s business is selling basic need food items  from a small neighborhood grocery store. She sells bread, sugar, soft drinks, cookies, sweets, Kool-Aid-type drink mixes, and other items. “I am trying to revitalize my store, which is a meeting place for neighbors…,” she comments. The advantage her business has is that the neighbors meet there to talk and to buy. The disadvantage is the lack of merchandise she has to offer. Her dream is to be the neighborhood’s preferred store. She wants to buy food to stock her business. This is her first loan cycle with the institution in the year that she has had this business. 

Ana is requesting a loan to stock her business so her store will become the one that's preferred by the people in her neighborhood.

loans.use: to stock her small grocery store so that it will become the one that is most preferred by the people in her neighborhood.

loans.name: Hulda

texts.es: A sus 25 años de edad Hulda muestra cada día sus deseos de superación ya que cuenta con una venta de tortas y bebidas, actividad que realiza desde hace 2 años, contando con una gran cantidad de clientes que solicitan sus productos. Hulda vive en casa de su propiedad desde hace varios años, junto a su hijo de 9 años de edad, además de sus hermanos. Ella desea invertir en su negocio, para cumplir con la demanda de productos con que cuenta, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: repollo, panes, carne, jamón, aguacate, entre otros productos para aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en:
At 25 years old, Hulda shows each day her desire to improve since she carries out a sale of sandwiches and drinks, an occupation she has been doing for two years now, counting on a large number of customers who request her products.

Hulda has lived in a house of her own for several years with her 9-year-old son, along with her siblings. She wishes to invest in her business to meet the demand of products that she relies on, which is why she is requesting a loan to FUSAI to invest in cabbage, bread, meat, ham, and avocado, among other products to increase her sales.

loans.use: to invest in cabbage, bread, meat, ham, and avocado, among other products to increase her sales.

loans.name: Gemmalyn

texts.en:
Gemmalyn is 42 years old, married and has three children. She has been managing a store at the public market for over a year now. Some of her customers requested more goods to be in her store, and that is why she wants to diversify her business.

She is now asking for a loan of 25,000 PHP to buy grocery items to for resale, such as canned goods, bread, eggs and soft drinks. She hopes to maintain a profitable business and save money for use to provide for any emergency needs of her family.

She will also continue sending her children to school and always extend good service to all her customers.

loans.use: to buy grocery items to for resale, such as canned goods, bread, eggs and soft drinks.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en: Marivic is 41 years old and married. Her family lives in Solana. She is managing a store for income. She sells grocery items to the people in their village. Though she gets minimal income in her business, she still manages it well so it will become profitable. She is asking for additional capital to increase her stock of merchandise. She is asking for PHP25,000 to buy canned goods, beverages, noodles, soap and shampoo to sell. This will help increase her sales and profits for her family. She promises to pay back her loan in full.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages, noodles, soap and shampooo to sell

loans.name: Babra

texts.en:
Babra, age 37, is a mother of five children. Her husband owns an jewelry shop in the market which is the only source of income for the family. Her husband needs to purchase new bangles and jewelry to resell. However her husband finds it difficult due to lack of money. This loan will help him offer more variety to his customers and to continue his work efficiently and professionally. His wife, Babra is requesting a loan from Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan with the goal of helping her husband.
Her husband will purchase new varieties of jewelry and bangles. Babra is feeling happy that she will be able to help her husband with the loan funds. She is thankful to Kiva lenders and to BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy bangles her husband's jewelry business

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina, who is in her early 30s, is single with one child who attends school. Amina has been running two businesses -- selling charcoal and running a beauty salon -- for one-and-a-half years now. She works from 7:00am to 6.45pm daily. and is able to make a very good monthly profit.

This will be Amina's third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to start the salon business and to increase her charcoal inventory, and she has managed to pay back all her loans successfully. She used the profits to pay school fees, to repay the loans, to buy a plot of land and to cover household expenses.

She will use this loan to buy sacks of charcoal for resale, as well as to buy salon products.

She dreams of finishing building her house.

Amina will be accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy sacks of  charcoal for resale, as well as to  buy salon products.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta is a married woman. She has four children. She describes herself to be capable. She operates a retail business where she sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a busy area, and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

She will use the KES 60,000 loan to buy more stock of charcoal. She hopes that in the future, she will be prosperous. This is her fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees.

loans.use: to buy more stock of charcoal.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is 62 years old and runs a small business selling rice. Since the Filipino diet consists of rice during meals, rice has really a high demand. She lives in Duero, Bohol. She has been selling rice for 10 years so she can raise her family.

Patricia has requested a loan from CEVI to use as additional capital to buy more rice to sell, buy a new weighing scale and piglets to raise. This investment will help her expand her business and earn larger profits.

It is her dream to be sustainable so that someday she will not resort to loans to make her business successful.

loans.use: to buy rice, a weighing scale and piglets.

loans.name: Kolë

texts.en:
Kole is 53 and a married man to Lule, his wife who is in the photograph. They have been doing agriculture/livestock work the past twenty five years. Their family owns about ten dynym of agricultural land where they mainly plant corn and wheat which they use for feeding animals and for family consumption. 

They also have two pig sows and two pigs at the moment. They sell piglets and male pigs. 

"We always managed to have a dairy cow, and the last one past away suddenly, thus, we need to replace that because we need milk and also dairy products for ourselves," said Lule to the loan officer during the disbursement interview. 

The reason for this loan is to replace a dairy cow that just passed away. 

In addition to agriculture, Kole works as a driver with a school minibus for a monthly pay of $190.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a married woman. She has four children. She operates a poultry farm, where she keeps chickens. Her primary customers are hotels. She describes her biggest business challenge to be poultry diseases.

She will use the 100,000 KES loan to buy more chickens.

She hopes that in the future, she will be able to educate her children to university level.

This is Margaret's fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to purchase additional chickens.

loans.use: to buy more chickens.

loans.name: Yobana Marisol

texts.es:
Yobana con 36 años de edad ,de estado civil conviviente,vive en casa propia, junto a su cónyuge y su hijo, en el distrito de Oyotún,provincia de Chiclayo,departamento Lambayeque,país Perú, en una zona rural. Los habitantes de esta localidad se dedican en su mayoría a la agricultura,comercio y ganadería.

Yobana tiene su bodega en la cuál vende productos de primera necesidad, con una experiencia en el rubro hace 02 años,su negocio se encuentra ubicado en su domicilio.Solicita préstamo para invertir en capital de trabajo, compra de arroz, azúcar, fideo, aceite, etc, esto le servirá para tener mayor variedad en lo concerniente a productos de primera necesidad esto con la finalidad de poder satisfacer los gustos de sus clientes y así poder incrementar sus ventas.

Yobana es socio recurrente para Edpyme Alternativa.
texts.en:
Yobana is 36 years old, and she is married. She has her own home, and lives with her husband and son in the district of Oyotún, which is located in the Chiclayo province in the Lambayeque region of Perú. They live in a rural area where the residents make a living mainly in agriculture, commerce and ranching.

Yobana has a convenience store where she sells basic necessities. She has 2 years of experience working in this profession. She runs her business out of her home. She is requesting a loan to invest in working capital, as well as to buy rice, sugar, noodles, oil, and more. This will enable her to have a larger variety of basic necessities, and with this she will be able to meet the demands of her customers and increase her sales.

Yobana is a recurring member of Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to invest in working capital, as well as buy rice, sugar, noodles, oil, and more.

loans.name: Shumaila

texts.en:
Shumaila is a 34-year-old woman residing in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband is the guardian of the family and responsible for fulfilling the needs of all family members. Shumaila has been running her own cosmetics store for the past three years. She also contributes her income with her husband to manage the household.

She needs to buy different types of cosmetics such as creams, hair brushes, and other accessories for business purposes, but due to financial constraints she is not capable of buying these items. Therefore, Shumaila has applied for a Kiva loan. This loan will help her to buy the relevant items for her business purpose so that she can provide better services to her customers. It will also help her to earn the maximum profitable income to fulfill the needs of her business and family.

For this financial assistance, Shumaila is very grateful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to increase her cosmetics business.

loans.name: Franklin Oswaldo

texts.es:
Franklin, de 21 años de edad, actualmente estudia segundo año de la carrera licenciatura en administración de empresas, está soltero y no tiene hijos, vive junto a su madre y sus dos hermanas.

Franklin, es un joven con muchos deseos de superación, es por eso que actualmente está estudiando una carrera universitaria, gracias al sacrificio de su madre; pero aparte de estudiar también tiene una tienda junto a su madre, de donde obtienen ingresos para cubrir los gastos de sus estudios.

El préstamo será invertido para comprar más mercadería como arroz, azúcar, frijoles, pan, café, entre otros productos para surtir la tienda.
 
El sueño de Franklin, es graduarse de la universidad y de esta forma ayudar a su madre y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Franklin is 21 years old. He is currently in his second year of college studying business administration. He is single without children. He lives with his mother and his two sisters.

Franklin is a young man who desires to improve in many ways. For this reason, he is currently studying at a university, thanks to the sacrifice of his mother. In addition to studying, he also runs a store with his mother through which they earn income to take care of educational expenses.

The loan will be used to buy more merchandise such as rice, sugar, beans, bread, coffee and more to stock the inventory of their store.

Franklin's dream is to graduate from college, and help his mother as well as improve the quality of life for his family.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise such as rice, sugar, beans, bread, coffee and more to stock the inventory of her store.

loans.name: Rajmonda

texts.en:
Rajmonda has been sick lately and is scheduled for chemotherapy sessions. This is the reason she needs your financial help. She is 51 and a mother of two, with the youngest one being just 16 years old. The last two years, despite the struggles with her own health, she started an agriculture activity. On the eight-dynym agricultural land that her family owns, she planted apples in four dynym, pears in two dynym and cherries in the other two dynyms. The annual gross revenue from the apples is $2370, $790 from the pears and $1265 from the cherries.

"The money I have been making from the activity has been going mostly to my therapies and medications. Even though I have been sick, I have managed to work, yet, lately I cannot at all. My older son who is 25 has now joined his father in the activity," said Rajmonda to the loan officer who visited her at home.

loans.use: to pay for her chemotherapy sessions that have already been scheduled

loans.name: Dúo Misericordia Group

texts.es:
Dúo Misericordia

Este dúo lo integran Ángela es propietaria de una tienda de productos comestibles y mini librería, en sus pagos es bien responsable. Su negocio lo tiene en su comunidad y le ayuda bastante el ser la única tienda y librería cercana, se ha esforzado por tener surtido su negocio y atender desde muy temprano. Agradece a Kiva y Fape el gran apoyo que les brindan  y desea muchas bendiciones para ustedes. Ella lucha día a día por su hija ya que desea que tenga los estudios que ella no pudo tener y tener así más y mejores oportunidades en la vida. Solicita el crédito para la compra de artículos de consumo diario(productos comestibles) y materiales para librería.
texts.en:
Dúo Misericordia

Ángela is a member of this dúo. She is the owner of a grocery store and mini-bookstore. She is very responsible with her payments. Her business is located in her community, and it helps that hers is the only grocery store and mini-bookstore in the area. This has forced her to keep her businesses well-stocked and open very early in the morning.

Ángela thanks Kiva and Fape for the great help which they provide to her, and she wishes for many blessings for them. She strives daily for her daughter since Ángela would like to give her daughter the education that she was never able to receive, and through this, her daughter will have more and better opportunities in life.

Ángela is requesting a loan to buy groceries and products for her bookstore.

loans.use: to buy groceries to sell.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma is a mother of four children. Her eldest is 19 years old and the youngest is 11 years old. Her husband works abroad just to provide for them. In return, Emma works hard so that she can help her husband, even if he is far away.

She raises hogs and sells frozen foods. She is in need of additional capital to expand her business. She will use it to buy longanisa (cured, sweet pork sausage), chorizo (spanish sausage) and ham. She hopes to see her business becoming successful and for her children to finish their schooling too.

loans.use: to buy longanisa (cured, sweet pork sausage), chorizo (spanish sausage) and ham for resale.

loans.name: Esperanza Del Carmen

texts.es: Doña Esperanza de 52 años de edad vive en casa propia con sus dos hijas y su nieta, ella se dedica a la venta de tamales de gallina desde hace 5 años vende de manera ambulante por las diferentes colonias que estan cerca de su casa, gracias a sus ventas es como puede salir adelante con los gastos de su hogar, ella esta solicitando un credito para la compra de maiz, verduras, hojas de huerta para envolverlos, pollo, entre otras cosas y asi tener mejores ingresos economicos.
texts.en:
Doña Esperanza is 52 years old, and she has her own home where she lives with her two daughters and granddaughter. She has made a living selling chicken tamales for 5 years. She travels to the various areas around where she lives to sell her product. Thanks to her sales, she is able to get ahead and take care of the household expenses.

She is requesting a loan to buy corn, vegetables, banana leaves for wrapping, chicken, and more. Through this, she will earn more income.

loans.use: to buy corn, vegetables, banana leaves for wrapping, chicken, and more.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice, who is in her late 20s, is single with two children. One of them is still small and the other one is still in school. She has been running several projects: she has been a food vendor and has been selling fabrics and madila for three years now. She works from 6am to 5pm daily and is able to make a monthly report.

This will be Beatrice's fifth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase her mamalishe stock and start selling fabrics and madila. She has managed to pay back all her loans successfully. She is doing great with her loan. She used the profit to repay the loan, to pay school fees for her kid, to build her house, buy a flat screen TV set and a radio and covered household expenses.

Beatrice will be accountable for paying back her loan.

loans.use: to restock the out of stock items in her mamalishe, to increase her fabric stock and to buy in-fashion madila.

loans.name: Loise

texts.en:
Loise is a married woman. She has five children. She operates a retail business, where she sells sugar, bread, flour, sweets and other items. She has been involved in this business for ten years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. 

She will use the 50,000 KES loan to buy more stock of sugar, bread, soap, flour, rice and other items. She hopes that in the future, she will have an improved standard of living. 

This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, bread, soap, flour, rice and other items.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas is a married man. He has two children. He describes himself to be focused. He operates a retail business, where he sells sugar, bread, flour, sweets and other items. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located in a busy area and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. 

He will use the 100,000 KES loan to buy more stock of sugar, bread, soap, flour, rice and other items. His business goal is to have a wholesale shop within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will be able to educate his children to university level. 

This is his fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to buy land.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, bread, soap, flour, rice and other items.

loans.name: Jose Saul

texts.es:
Jose, ya es cliente recurrente y ahora se acerca nuevamente para solicitar un crédito, ya que quiere realizar la compra de una cámara profesional para continuar fortaleciendo su fuente de trabajo, José pretende aumentar su equipo de trabajo que le permitirá obtener más ingresos para continuar dándole una buena calidad de vida a su familia.
José comenta que continua manteniendo las mismas condiciones económicas pero las circunstancias familiares han mejorado considerablemente. Gracias a los créditos él puede mantener con vida su negocio.
texts.en:
José is already a repeat customer and is again returning to request a loan. He wants to purchase a professional camera to continue strengthening his source of employment. José aims to add to his work equipment which will allow him to obtain more income to continue providing a good quality of life to his family.

José notes that he continues to maintain the same financial situation but that his family's conditions have improved considerably. Thanks to the loans, he has been able to keep his business alive.

loans.use: to buy a professional camera to continue strengthening his source of employment.

loans.name: Nest

texts.en:
Nest is photographed with his wife, Bardhe (or 'white' in English) and their oldest child, who is 15. Their youngest is just six years old.

For the past 15 years, their focus has been mostly on livestock, since they own no land where they can plant. "We have only 400 square meters of land, where we plant only for our consumption. As far as the livestock goes, currently, we've got a dairy cow, 13 goats and a saw. We sell only one calf per year and also piglets, keeping the raw milk for the family. Our children are growing now and so are their expenses. This is why we thought of adding more goats to the business, in order to sell homemade goat cheese and baby goats," said Nest to the branch assistant.

Nest also works for a monthly pay of $260, and the family also receives social assistance in an amount of $51/month.

Your loan will be used to add some more goats to the existing herd and to build a toilet and a sewage system for the family's house.

loans.use: to buy goats, as well as to build a toilet in the family's house where three young children live.

loans.name: Rani

texts.en:
Rani is a 44-year-old woman. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. She has been running a food stall, where she sells different types of eatable items for school, e.g samosa, vegetable rolls, pakoras, tea, etc. She is responsible for feeding the entire family and managing the household.

Rani needs to purchase different types of eatable and other items for her business so that she can increase the size of the business, improve her sales, and earn maximum profits. However, due to an unfavorable financial position, she is not in condition to purchase these items for her business purposes.
Therefore, Rani has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner, BRAC Pakistan, so that she can purchase the above items for her business.

She is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to increase the size of her food stall business.

loans.name: Oswaldo

texts.es:
Oswaldo con 32 años de edad, de estado civil separado,vive en casa propia,junto a su hijo,hermano y cuñada, en el distrito de Cayaltí,provincia de Chiclayo,departamento de Lambayeque,país Perú. Los habitantes de esta localidad se dedican en su mayoría a la agricultura,comercio y ganadería.

Oswaldo se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales de corral. Adiconalmente ofrece mano de obra agrícola y en las tardes opcionalmente maneja mototaxi. Solicita préstamo para la compra de animales para venta y arreglos de techo de calamina en casa. De esta manera obtendrá mayor venta y atención y así poder generar mayores ingresos para una mejora en calidad de vida.

Oswaldo con experiencia crediticia con Edpyme Alternativa, con pagos puntuales.
texts.en:
Oswaldo is 32 years old, and he is currently separated. He lives in his own home with his son, brother, and sister-in-law. They live in the district of Cayaltí in the Chiclayo province, in the Lambayeque region of Perú. The residents of this area make a living mainly in agriculture, commerce, and ranching.

Oswaldo makes a living raising and selling farmyard animals. Additionally, he works as an agricultural laborer, and in the evenings he drives a motorcycle taxi. He is requesting a loan to buy animals which he will sell, and to fix the corrugated iron roof of his house. Through this, his sales will improve and his business will attract attention, and as a result he will be able to earn more income for a better quality of life.

Oswaldo has credit experience with Edpyme Alternativa, and his payments have been on time.

loans.use: to buy animals which he will sell, as well as to repair the corrugated iron roof of his house.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a married mother of two children. She describes herself to be reliable.

Grace operates a retail business where she sells sugar, cakes, bread, flour, sweets and other items. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

Grace will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, rice, cakes, flour and other items. Her business goal is to open a cereal store within five years.

This is Grace's first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children.
